security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate GIF creation toolkit. All 123 static findings are false positives: the scanner incorrectly flagged animation 'algorithms' as cryptographic code, mathematical constants (c1, c2, c3) as C2 keywords, and documentation code blocks as shell execution. The skill uses only local image processing libraries (PIL, numpy, imageio) with no network calls, credential access, or malicious patterns.

content.user_title: Create Slack GIFs and emoji animations
content.value_statement: Creating GIFs for Slack requires careful optimization to meet strict file size limits. This toolkit provides validators, animation primitives, and optimization tools so you can create message GIFs and emoji reactions that upload successfully.
actual_capabilities: Create message GIFs up to 2MB with frame-by-frame animation
Build emoji GIFs under 64KB limit with color optimization
Apply 12 animation primitives (shake, bounce, spin, pulse, fade, zoom, etc.)
Validate GIF dimensions and file size against Slack requirements
Use easing functions for smooth natural motion
Add visual effects like particles, motion blur, and impact flashes
limitations: Requires Python with pillow, imageio, and numpy installed
Generated GIFs must be manually uploaded to Slack
Emoji rendering depends on system font support
File size optimization requires careful frame and color management

use_cases.title: Team reaction GIFs
use_cases.description: Build custom emoji reactions for team celebrations, approvals, or humor under 64KB

use_cases.title: Animated announcements
use_cases.description: Create animated message GIFs for announcements, demos, or highlights within Slack limits

use_cases.title: Automated GIF workflows
use_cases.description: Generate GIFs programmatically for CI/CD notifications, status updates, or bot responses

prompt_templates.title: Simple emoji GIF
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an emoji GIF for Slack showing [emoji] pulsing in size. Use 128x128 pixels, 15 frames, and save it under 64KB.

prompt_templates.title: Reaction animation
prompt_templates.prompt: Make a Slack emoji GIF where [emoji1] shakes horizontally then transforms into [emoji2]. Keep it under 64KB with 12 frames.

prompt_templates.title: Impact effect
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 480x480 message GIF with [emoji] bouncing then exploding into particles. Use 30 frames at 20 fps.

prompt_templates.title: Complex composition
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a Slack-ready GIF with [emoji1] sliding in from left while [emoji2] pulses in the center. Add a flash effect on impact.

output_examples.input: Create a shaking reaction emoji GIF with the mind blown emoji under 64KB
output: Created shake animation with 20 frames at intensity 15
Applied ease_out_quad easing for natural decay

output_examples.input: Build a bouncing ball animation with impact flash for message GIF
output: Created 30 frames with ease_in gravity simulation
Added impact flash effect on frames 25-27

best_practices: For emoji GIFs, limit to 10-12 frames and 32-48 colors maximum to stay under 64KB
Use optimize_for_emoji=True when saving emoji GIFs for aggressive compression
Validate file size frequently during development using check_slack_size()
anti_patterns: Using more than 12 frames for emoji GIFs (will likely exceed 64KB)
Forgetting to validate dimensions before building complex animations
Using high frame rates (30+ fps) for emoji GIFs unnecessarily

faq.question: What is the difference between message GIFs and emoji GIFs?
faq.answer: Message GIFs appear in chat with 2MB limit and 480x480 optimal. Emoji GIFs are reactions with strict 64KB limit and 128x128 optimal.

faq.question: How do I keep my emoji GIF under 64KB?
faq.answer: Limit to 10-12 frames, use 32-48 colors, avoid gradients, and use optimize_for_emoji=True when saving.

faq.question: Can I use this with Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code for programmatic GIF generation in automation workflows.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill only processes images locally using Python libraries. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why is my GIF too large even with optimization?
faq.answer: Check frame count, color count, and dimensions. Try reducing frames to 10-12 and colors to 32-40 for emoji GIFs.

faq.question: How does this compare to online GIF makers?
faq.answer: This skill provides programmatic control for automation. Online tools offer UI but cannot be integrated into workflows.
